entry.title: 新しい認定試験方式受けてみた
entry.content:
はじめに

先日アナウンスがあったとおり、SAPの認定試験が、これまでの選択式の試験からより実践的な試験に変更になるようです。
https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-learning-blog-posts/reimagining-certification-for-the-way-we-work-today/ba-p/14261141

現時点では一部の試験だけですが「2026年までに 、 すべてのSAP認定資格がこの新しい実践的な形式に移行します。」と記載されています。

  • 実技試験には2種類あるってことだけど、システム・ベース、シナリオ・ベースそれぞれどんな感じなの？
  • 英語で対応する必要がある？
  • オープンブック形式ってことだけど監督は全然されないってこと？

などが気になりつつ、さっそくチャレンジしてきました。

この記事は SAPアドベントカレンダー 2025 の 12月1日分の記事として執筆しています。

共通すること

  • 予約は不要になりました。いつでも好きなタイミングで受験できます。試験の監督官はつきません。
  • システムベースかシナリオベースかは、試験ごとにあらかじめ決まっています。おそらく、開発系の試験はシステムベース、アプリ系の試験はシナリオベースになるのだと思います。
  • このページをちゃんと読むと書いてありますが、Start Certification Examを押してから24hのカウントがあり、そのあとのステップに進むボタンを押してから2h（試験によっては3h）以内に終了する必要があります。システムベースだと、Access Practice Examをクリックしたタイミング、シナリオベースの場合、AIとのロールプレイにするかビデオ提出にするかを選択したタイミングです。
  • 各試験の案内ページのPrepare for Certification から行ける Learning Journey がためになるので、試験受けるか迷っていても、のぞいてみるのをおすすめします。たぶん、Learning Hub 持っていなくてもアクセスできます（ものによるのかも）

システム・ベース受けてみた（SAP Generative AI Developer）

1か月の無料トライアルを申し込んだときと同じような、IDのすでに決まった環境が割り当てられます。手順PDFがダウンロードできるので、その指示に従って環境に設定を行っていきます。

  • PDFは英語ですが、オープンブック形式ということは翻訳手段は何とでもなるのでハードルにはならないかと思います。
  • 各ステップの完了目安時間が示されているので、時間配分に気を付けながら進めていく必要があります。
  • Learning Journey の Practical Exercise を理解していれば、問題なく進められる内容でした。

シナリオ・ベース受けてみた（SAP Business Data Cloud）

スタートすると、「Yoodliを始める」というボタンとともに、カメラとマイクをONにしろ、と言われてビビりますが、回答内容を認識するためのものなので気楽にONにしてください。SAP Business Data Cloud の導入を検討しているユーザによる面接という体で、様々な質問をされるので、それに回答していきます。

  • AI、日本語で話してくれます！ので、もちろん日本語で答えれば大丈夫です。
  • 途中で通信状態が悪かったのか画面が固まってしまい進めずに焦りましたが、リロードしたら問題なく最初からやり直しになりました。（Don’t close this page と表示されていたのでビクビクしながら更新しましたが大丈夫でした）
  • オープンブック形式ということで、質問されてから色々見て回答を探しながら回答できます。そうすると、質問されてからかなり沈黙の時間が流れてしまいますが、そこは問題なさそうでした。ちゃんと回答を話し出すまで待ってくれます。
  • AIからの質問が終わると、スコアが表示されます。分野ごとに、どれくらいのレベルで回答できていたかが示されます。
  • このときに、AIの質問と自分の回答の文字起こしも表示されるので「文字起こしをコピー」ボタンでコピーしてどこかに保存することができます
  • 最初のスコアで合格ラインを越えられなかったのですが、時間内であれば最初からやり直すことができ、試験回数を追加で消費せずに合格することができました

おわりに

監督する人との会話がなく、部屋を見せる必要も身分証明書を出す必要もない試験、気楽でした！

試験の難易度的にも、かなり楽になってしまったのではないかと感じました。ここはこのまま行って大丈夫なのか、疑問が残ります。と言ってもシナリオベースで頑張ったつもりで67％のスコアしか取れなかったので、その領域についての知識の地図が頭にできてないと、厳しそうです。

以前の選択式のテストも、認定取ったからってその領域のコンサルとして明日から働けるか？はわからなかったわけで、「この実践テストを乗り越えたということは、何かを参照にしながらなら問題解決できますね」という方が目的にかなっているということなのかもしれません。

entry.title: How I Escaped Browser Tab Hell: A Lesson in Choosing the Right AI Tool
entry.content:
The Journey

The Problem: 10 Years of Digital Hoarding

After a decade at SAP, I was drowning in resources. My solution? Browser bookmarks that grew into an unmanageable mess. When Chrome introduced Tab Groups, I thought I'd found salvation—until I realized I was maintaining 200+ tabs across multiple groups. The anxiety from my digital FOMO was worse than ever.

Back to Basics (With a Twist)

I returned to curated bookmarks but with a new goal: create a "PM Toolbox" that I could easily maintain and share with colleagues across the organization. I built a clean bookmark folder and mirrored it on a wiki page.

The Maintenance Nightmare

Within weeks, reality hit: my bookmark folder evolved constantly, requiring manual wiki updates. Chrome's bookmark export format (the ancient Netscape standard) made extracting subsets error-prone and frustrating. I needed automation.

First Attempt: GenAI Fails the Coding Test

I tried using Claude 4.5 Sonnet through GenAI-XL. Despite multiple attempts, it couldn't handle Chrome's non-standard HTML format. It kept reaching for HTML parsing libraries that failed, then suggested an obscure Netscape parser that violated SAP standards. Dead end.

Second Attempt: GitHub Copilot Nails It

The next day, I switched to VSCode with GitHub Copilot. Here's what changed:
  1. I wrote clear requirements in a `.github/copilot-instructions.md` file, specifically calling out the Netscape format complexity
  2. Copilot enhanced my requirements, suggesting testing coverage and documentation guidelines (80% of the final instructions came from Copilot)
  3. I switched to Agent mode and prompted: "Please create the missing files. Do not reference public code in your response." (Critical for enterprise compliance)
The result? A complete, working script—instantly.

But it got better. When I asked for a second script to generate Confluence tables, Copilot:
  • Created the implementation
  • Built the test suite when I requested it
  • Ran the tests autonomously, discovered bugs, and fixed them—all without me asking
I was genuinely amazed.

Key Takeaways

1. Match the Tool to the Task

  • General AI (like Claude): Excellent for brainstorming, requirements refinement, and PM tasks
  • Specialized coding AI (like GitHub Copilot): Purpose-built for implementation and testing

2. Clear Requirements Are Non-Negotiable

Both attempts used AI, but only the second succeeded because I provided structured, detailed requirements upfront.

3. Embrace Test-Driven Development

Even with AI assistance, automated testing is essential. Copilot's self-correction only worked because tests exposed the bugs immediately.

4. Simple Solutions Often Win

Sometimes the answer isn't a shinier tool—it's going back to basics (curated bookmarks) with smart automation layered on top.

The Bottom Line

AI coding assistants aren't magic—they're power tools. Like any tool, they require the right context, clear instructions, and quality controls. When you provide those, the results can be transformative.

For PMs and non-developers: you don't need to be a coder to automate your work. You just need to understand your requirements so you can clearly write them down and choose the AI tool designed for the job.

References

You can find the scripts in question here

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Paraguay 2025: Premios de SAP Press, los grandes ganadores de la noche
entry.content:
Durante el año 2025 organizamos el primer SAP Inside Track en Paraguay Ciudad del Este, un evento histórico donde más de 100 profesionales SAP se reunieron para compartir conocimientos, hacer networking y celebrar nuestra pasión por la tecnología.


¿Por Qué Participar en un SAP Inside Track?
Los eventos SAP Inside Track son espacios únicos donde la comunidad SAP cobra vida:

  • Aprender de expertos con experiencia real en proyectos SAP
  • Hacer networking con consultores, desarrolladores y usuarios clave
  • Mantenerse actualizado con las últimas tendencias y mejores prácticas
  • Compartir experiencias y soluciones con colegas del ecosistema SAP
  • Fortalecer la comunidad local y crear conexiones profesionales duraderas

Gracias a Todos
Nuestro más sincero agradecimiento a quienes hicieron posible este evento: los asistentes por su entusiasmo y participación, los speakers por compartir su conocimiento, los voluntarios por su dedicación incansable, y todos los sponsors por creer en nuestra visión y apoyar el crecimiento de la comunidad SAP en Paraguay.


Un Agradecimiento Especial a SAP Press
Queremos destacar especialmente el apoyo de SAP Press, quien como patrocinador oficial del evento, contribuyó significativamente a hacer de este SIT una experiencia inolvidable. SAP Press no solo aportó su prestigio y respaldo al evento, sino que también puso a disposición de los participantes 4 e-books de su catálogo como premios durante el evento.
Este tipo de apoyo es fundamental para motivar la participación, premiar el compromiso de nuestra comunidad y brindar acceso a recursos de aprendizaje de primera calidad. SAP Press ha sido y continúa siendo un aliado invaluable en el desarrollo profesional de miles de profesionales SAP en todo el mundo.

¡Felicitaciones a Nuestros Ganadores!
Durante el evento, tuvimos el placer de sortear 4 e-books de SAP Press entre nuestros participantes. Nos complace anunciar a los afortunados ganadores:

  • Blanca Lezme

  • Martha Ayala Jara 

  • Pablo Jorge Berganza Carvallo

  • Vanessa Maria Jose Guillen Argüello

¡Felicitaciones a todos los ganadores! Esperamos que disfruten de sus libros y que el conocimiento adquirido les sea de gran utilidad en sus carreras profesionales.

Mirando Hacia el Futuro
El éxito de este primer SAP Inside Track Paraguay nos llena de orgullo y nos motiva a seguir adelante. Nuestro compromiso es claro: queremos que este sea el primero de muchos eventos.
Ya estamos soñando con el SAP Inside Track Paraguay 2026, y esperamos contar nuevamente con el apoyo de sponsors como SAP Press, con más participantes, más contenido de calidad y, por supuesto, ¡más premios para nuestra comunidad!

¿Quieres Ser Parte del Próximo Evento?
Si participas en nuestro próximo SAP Inside Track, no solo tendrás acceso a contenido de primer nivel y oportunidades de networking invaluables, sino que también podrás participar en sorteos de premios como los e-books de SAP Press y otros beneficios que nuestros sponsors pondrán a disposición.

No te pierdas la oportunidad de ser parte de esta comunidad vibrante y en crecimiento.

Mantente atento a nuestros canales oficiales para conocer las fechas y detalles del próximo evento. Mientras tanto, te invitamos a unirte a la SAP Community Group de Asunción para estar al día con todas las novedades.

¡Gracias y Hasta Pronto!
Desde el equipo organizador del SAP Inside Track Paraguay, queremos agradecer una vez más a todos los que hicieron posible este sueño. Este es solo el comienzo de algo grande.

¡Nos vemos en el próximo SAP Inside Track Paraguay!

¿Quieres saber más sobre SAP Press y su catálogo de libros? Visita www.sap-press.com

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: SAP TechEd on Tour brought the best out of Berlin, Bengaluru, and Sydney!
entry.content:
As SAP TechEd on Tour continues to inspire people around the world, our SAP community is buzzing with fresh insights, great lessons, and standout contributions from Developer Advocates, SAP Champions and Mentors, and members from local groups. This edition of our newsletter brings you some of the blog posts that dive deeper into the most talked-about topics from SAP TechEd in Berlin, Bengaluru and Sydney. Whether you joined the events in person or are catching up virtually, these resources will help you to keep the innovation energy high and inspired to thrive on the SAP topics. 

Beyond technical content, we’re also spotlighting the vibrant connections forming at the SAP Community in-person gatherings. From post-sessions reflections to personal stories, these posts reflect the passion and collaboration that make our community grow. We’re excited to share not only the knowledge but also the experiences and inspiration that emerged through the month of November. So, dive in and keep the momentum going! 

Featured Blog Posts 

Follow-up of the “Best of UI5“ demo presented at SAP TechEd in Bengaluru 

One of the highlights of SAP TechEd on Tour was the amazing demos presented by our Community Advocates and Developer Advocates. At the SAP TechEd in Bengaluru last week, Nico Schoenteich demoed the flexibility and openness of UI5 by showing two approaches for extending UI5 application with custom elements. As a follow-up to his demo presented at the Developer Keynote, he published a blog post about how to consume arbitrary web components natively in UI5 applications. Whether you were on-site and are looking for more information, or could not attend but are interested in the topic, we highly recommend checking his content for valuable advice to make the process decreasingly complicated. 

Read Nico Schoenteich blog post here 

SAP Integration Suite: guide to secure you integrations and compliance best practices  

Our SAP Community member Praveen Kumar Beera, beyond attending SAP TechEd 2025, also made sure to share more important tips on SAP Integration Suite. In his latest blog post, Praveen dives into how to implement and manage access policies effectively, focusing on the importance of securing your integrations and maintaining robust governance. His step-by-step guide has all the images, examples, and links that you need to understand how to archive a better security setup and reduce risks.  

Read Praveen kumar Beera blog post here 

SAP TechEd on Tour: Sessions using SAP Mobile Start 

SAP Mobile Start is the native entry point to the SAP Business Suite, providing access to native or web-responsive business apps along with other content and critical business information. At SAP TechEd in Berlin and Bengaluru, SAP´s  Thilo Berndt and Thomas Bruckner, covered various mobile topics at workshops called "CA260 – Learn how to build your own app and use it in SAP Mobile Start". In Thomas’ latest blog post, he shared a full recap with the main technical aspects and valuable material for introduction, building and deploying the base version of the extension, app integration, and extensions, plus the implementation of custom push notifications. The on-site sessions were centered on the ease of building pro-code extensions using SAP Build and specifically SAP Build Code with the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). And if you could not take part and want to have a chance to try it out, they also uploaded all the material and exercises on GitHub within the repository  SAP-samples/teched2025-CA260.  

Read Thomas Bruckner blog post here 

Everything you need to know to start with SAP Business Data Cloud 

At SAP TechEd in Sydney, SAP´s Klaus-Peter Sauer presented great sessions around SAP Business Data Cloud, bringing an insightful overview and focusing on growing solutions to the product road map. In case you had the opportunity to watch the session or could not be present but are looking for more information about the topic, recently one of our SAP community members Akhila Unnithan, published a great BDC Beginner Guide. Akhila shared the main key points to understand how the unified data platform works and how it can turn into the only source that provides everyone with a consistent and governed layer of data, whether it is for analytics, planning, or building AI Applications. She also explains what the existing SAP solutions are that form the foundation (SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP BW or BW/4HANA) and what the new components introduced specifically for SAP Business Data Cloud are (SAP Databricks and SAP Business Data Cloud Foundation Services). 

Read Akhila Unnithan blog post here 

SAP Community at SAP TechEd on Tour  

SAP TechEd in Berlin: recap by SAP Champion Patrizia Rossi 

“Superheroes without capes“ was the best term the SAP Champion Patrizia Rossi could use to describe our incredible SAP Community team. In her SAP TechEd in Berlin recap blog post, she walks through how the event was one to remember, starting with the fact that she was one of the rewarded SAP Champions who won the SAP TechEd ticket! With amazing pictures to illustrate the moments at the Developers Keynote and Community Clubhouse, Patrizia explains how she was impacted by the outgrowing Joule Agents and SAP Build, for tangible and smart automations directly from the development environment. Therefore, for her, the biggest spark is the fact that AI is no longer an experiment. Patrizia left the event feeling more inspired than ever, and honestly this is the feeling we wish for every single member of our SAP community.  

SAP TechEd in Sydney: connecting before and after 

For a lot of our SAP community members, the in-person connection is the biggest highlight of the SAP TechEd events. And in Sydney, beyond the experience of networking at the Community Theatre, the local community made sure to show up also for the pre-event Sydney Stammtisch. Organized by Mike Doyle and Jeff T., the meeting had around 70-80 attendees and plenty of insightful and honest conversations. It was also an incredible opportunity for our SAP Community Advocates, like Anne Petteroe and Josh Bentley, to finally meet in person many local group members and strengthen even more the connections that were once created online. If you attended and want to share your pictures, comment on Mike latest blog post and share with the community!   

SAP TechEd in Bengaluru: the most energetic and positive crowd  

“The energy, insightful conversations, and knowledge-sharing reaffirmed why this community is so special“ was our SAP Mentor Mohit Bansal description of his participation at the SAP TechEd in Bengaluru, and we also believe that this is the best way to put it. Just like past events, Bengaluru is always a place full of good and high-energy people, who are always seeking more innovation, more outcomes, and more real-life connections. Some of our amazing SAP Champions and Mentors could present great sessions and bring their expertise on-site, creating one of the best atmospheres for learning with purpose. One of the main key takeaways for many participants was the accelerating adoption of Business AI worldwide, but also how the complexities of this implementation can only be conquered with the support of all our community. We would like to highly recommend that everyone who was present share more of your experience in a blog post or, in case you are a member of the local community, bring your experience details and pictures at the Bengaluru Location group posts. 

News and Events 

ASUG Tech Connect 2025 in Louisville 

Recently one of our biggest events in the United States took place in Louisville, Kentucky, and brought light to many AI improvements for developers and businesses, the constant growth of ABAP, Clean Core for digital transformation, and many other SAP topics.  SAP´s Peter Spielvogel, wrote an amazing recap (blog post here) with the details of each one of his many Key Notes. But at ASUG Tech Connect, it was also an opportunity for the local community to come together, bring together ideas, and reflect on the importance of always remembering that people can grow from technological changes. Inspired by the sessions, Peter brought the question in his blog post: „How can I empower my people by asking them: What are you good at? What do you want? What do you need? What do you fear? This will help you preempt many objections that are rooted in these issues”, and we also believe that all these are mandatory self-reflecting questions. Did you take part? Do you have any other great thoughts about it? Share with us! 

SAP Webinar Open Source: Efficient Microservices Delivery with Project Konfidence 

This week, on December 4th, the SAP Open Source team is hosting another incredible webinar. This edition will be focused on Project Konfidence, a new open source that transforms the delivery of microservice-based SaaS applications. The discussion will be held by Sarah Müller, engineering manager and Konfidence project lead at SAP, and Timon Schüle, head of a software delivery framework at SAP, and hosted by Ulrike Fempel, SAP Open Source Program Office. Make sure to watch out for the time according to your time zone: 3 pm CET, 9 am EST and 7h30 pm IST.  Registration link for the event is here and more details about the event on the blog post here.  

Hobbies Series: Long-distance hiking 

We love to see that even with a month full of work like November was for most of us, our community members are still seeking life balance and taking their time for their passions. The SAP Community Hobbies Series, started by Moshe Naveh, inspired SAP´s Jan Rumig to share more about his love for hiking over thousands of kilometers. In his latest blog post, he explains that everything began with a family tradition that later became more intense, as he started spending two weeks exploring mountain regions. Illustrating with iconic pictures of his adventures in Portugal, New Zeeland, and Germany, for Jan the most wonderful feeling is when he reaches the final signpost after a long trail. If you are interested in starting to hike, we believe this content will give you the right motivation!

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite – Cloud integration Message Usage analytics details
entry.content:
Introduction

We are excited to share the latest improvements in SAP Integration Suite designed to support key business scenarios related to consumption-based usage tracking.

With these enhancements, users can now gain deeper insights into message consumption across their integration flows and easily download consolidated monthly usage reports.

Before we dive in, you can refer to the definitions of Instance and Message in Integration Suite here:

  • Tenant definition
  • Message definition

 

How to check Cloud Integration capability consumptions as a Subaccount Admin

If you are a subaccount admin and want to know the consumption of the cloud integration capability in Integration Suite service, follow these steps:

  1. Open your subaccount where Cloud Integration capability of Integration Suite service is activated.
  2. In the left navigation pane, click on Usage Analytics. This page displays the consumption details for all services.
  3. You can select a date range (Period) to view usage for a specific timeframe.
  4. After selecting the required period, the table will show detailed consumption for all services. In the table, check the “Service Plan” column for entries related to Integration Suite – messages.
  5. For Cloud Integration (CPI) messages, two entries are important:
    1. Total Cloud Integration Messages (e.g., 658 messages)
    2. Excluded Cloud Integration Messages (Only SAP to SAP) (e.g., 320 messages)
  6. Total Cloud Integration (CPI) Chargeable Messages = Total Cloud Integration Messages - Excluded Cloud Integration Messages.

 

 

In case we want to cross-verify this data at each integration flow level/MPL level, we need to navigate to the Messages Usage tile and follow the below steps:

  1. Ensure your user has the required role (PI_Administrator).
  2. Navigate to Instances and Subscriptions under the Services tab.
  3. Click Go to Application.
  4. Open the Monitoring tab and select Integrations and APIs.
  5. Scroll down to find the Messages Usage tile and click it.

On initial load, it will show the data for the current month.

 

 

Background

As many of you know, the Cloud Integration capability of SAP Integration Suite already provides double-click metering details for every integration flow execution.

Based on valuable feedback from our customers, this detailed view has proven useful in:

  • Troubleshooting message volume spikes
  • Identifying specific integration flow that contributes the most in message consumption
  • Understanding how key components (such as Splitter, Retry, or SAP-to-SAP Original Content) impact billable messages

These details are crucial for transparency and cost management, as outlined in the message definition documentation.

 

What’s New

Many customers expressed the need for a monthly consolidated Excel report for each integration flow — including package-level information.
With this new enhancement, users can now:

  • View consolidated monthly message consumption per integration flow and per package
  • Download the report directly from the Message Usage tile in a single click
  • Share usage data easily with Lines of Business (LoBs) for further analysis and discussions

 

Access the Message Usage tile explained above.

  1. Default view shows the current month.

When you open the Message Usage tile, the dashboard automatically loads data for the current month, giving you an immediate overview of your latest message consumption trends.

  1. New Enhancement – Below the chart you will see the consolidated table

This enhanced table provides:

  • Each integration flow’s total message count, including SAP-to-SAP messages
  • The package name associated with each integration flow
    This consolidated view helps you quickly understand usage distribution across packages and identify high-volume integrations.
  1. Download the monthly consolidated report

Simply click the Download button to export the full current monthly report.

 

 

 

Now try to get the previous month’s data

We provide up to 1 year of historical data. To get the previous month’s details, follow the steps below:

  1. Select the previous month’s first and last date

Use the Select Date Range option and choose the start and end dates of the month you want to retrieve.

  1. View the refreshed consolidated table

Once the date range is applied, the table below will automatically refresh, showing the consolidated message usage for the selected month.

  1. Download the monthly consolidated data

Click the Download button to export the full month’s report.
This file can be used for internal reviews, consumption analysis, or cost-related discussions with business teams.

 

 

Advanced Settings for Better Table Control

Along with the consolidated table, we also provide an Advanced Settings option.
Using this feature, you can:

  • Sort the data based on column
  • Filter records to focus on specific integration flows or packages
  • Adjust or reorder columns to view the information in the format that best suits your analysis

These options give you more flexibility to analyse message consumption in .

 

 

Enhanced Troubleshooting

This new capability extends our existing metering feature, which already helps users:

  • Investigate message spikes
  • Drill down into detailed metering data for specific integration flows
  • Use the interactive charts to visualize data based on selected metrics

Now, with the consolidated reporting feature, you get both detailed troubleshooting views and high-level monthly summaries — in one place.

Conclusion

Your feedback has been helpful in shaping these improvements — and we’d love to hear more!
Please share your thoughts, experiences, or suggestions for additional insights you’d like to see in Cloud Integration Capability.

entry.title: Безкоштовні тестові версії SAP
entry.content:
Безкоштовні тестові версії SAP: спробуйте найновіші технології без зобов’язань

SAP пропонує IT-фахівцям, аналітикам, розробникам та всім, хто цікавиться цифровими інноваціями, безкоштовно протестувати рішення компанії. На офіційних сторінках доступні пробні версії від 30 до 90 днів, які охоплюють ERP, аналітику, управління персоналом, ШІ та інші бізнес-рішення. Це можливість спробувати найновіші версії програмного забезпечення SAP для бізнесу, щоб підвищити ефективність, знизити ризики та забезпечити стабільну діяльність.

Basic Trials — ознайомлення з продуктами SAP з обмеженими правами адміністратора та зразками даних. За посиланням ви знайдете понад 30 доступних пробних версій рішень SAP по різним напрямкам: Artificial intelligence (AI), Data and analytics, Business technology platform, Cloud ERP applications, CRM and customer experience, Financial management, Human capital management, Spend management, Supply chain management, Sustainability management, Industries (SAP Cloud for Energy, SAP
E-Mobility, SAP Sports One, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, public sector).

Advanced Trials — розширені пробні версії з можливістю експериментувати з власними даними. За посиланням доступно більше 10 пробних версій по таким напрямкам: Business process transformation, Business technology platform, Cloud ERP applications, Supply chain management and Industries (SAP S/4HANA Utilities).

На цих сторінках також доступні demo videos та product tours, щоб швидко ознайомитися з функціоналом та потенціалом рішень SAP.

Тестові версії SAP — це можливість:

  • дослідити, як рішення SAP інтегруються у вашу IT-екосистему;
  • перевірити сценарії оптимізації бізнес-процесів;
  • протестувати ШI-моделі для аналітики, прогнозування та автоматизації.

Інтерактивні демонстрації — Value Journeys

SAP також пропонує Interactive Value Journey (IVJ) — це безкоштовні інтерактивні демонстрації SAP, що дозволяють побачити роботу бізнес-процесів у системі в реальному режимі. Кожна подорож містить покрокову інструкцію, коментарі та готові приклади даних, щоб користувач міг швидко зрозуміти, як працює конкретний сценарій. Доступ відкритий для всіх, тому IVJ є зручним способом ознайомитися з можливостями SAP без технічної підготовки та додаткових інсталяцій.

SAP Business Technology Platform (Build and develop) — ця інтерактивна подорож показує як цифрове рішення допомагає компаніям підвищувати ефективність і прискорювати цифрову трансформацію. У прикладі CIO компанії S.MART використовує інструменти SAP Build для оптимізації операцій, швидкої розробки рішень і автоматизації процесів. У результаті досягнено: кращий контроль запасів і узгодження між складами та магазинами, прозорість та узгодженість даних у всій компанії, гнучкі хмарні рішення, що швидко адаптуються до змін у бізнесі, швидке виявлення та усунення процесних проблем завдяки аналітиці й AI-підказкам. Переглянути подорож можна за посиланням – вона стає доступною після створення безкоштовного облікового запису на сайті SAP.

SAP Business Suite — інтерактивна подорож демонструє, як SAP Business Suite об’єднує додатки, дані та штучний інтелект у єдину платформу для управління бізнесом. У сценарії показано, як компанії можуть впроваджувати інтегровані рішення, що охоплюють всі функції: від фінансів і ланцюга постачання до HR та продажів.

  • Модульний підхід: вибір спеціалізованих пакетів для різних бізнес-процесів.
  • Єдина система даних з різних джерел, що забезпечує прозорість і узгодженість.
  • Вбудований ШІ: аналітика, автоматизація, агент-рішення для комплексної підтримки бізнесу.
  • Орієнтація на хмару та масштабованість для розвитку компанії.

Цей сценарій допомагає оцінити, як SAP Business Suite створює основу для бізнес-інновацій і цифрової трансформації. Сценарій доступний за посиланням після створення облікового запису SAP.

SAP Business AI – плейлист SAPPHIRE 2025. Цей плейлист присвячений можливостям штучного інтелекту в бізнесі (Business AI) від SAP, які були представлені на SAPPHIRE 2025. У добірці зібрані інтерактивні сценарії (IVJ), що показують, як ШІ допомагає компаніям оптимізувати процеси, автоматизувати рутинні операції та приймати кращі рішення на основі даних.

До плейлиста входить:

  • огляд ключових новинок Business AI від SAP;
  • демонстрації реальних бізнес-сценаріїв з використанням ШІ;
  • приклади інтеграції ШI у фінанси, операційні процеси, клієнтський сервіс та ланцюги постачання;
  • показ того, як ШІ підсилює продуктивність команд і пришвидшує цифрову трансформацію.

Ознайомтеся за посиланням. Для перегляду достатньо створити безкоштовний SAP-аккаунт.

Спробуйте SAP безкоштовно — і переконайтеся, як штучний інтелект, аналітика та автоматизація допомагають компаніям працювати ефективніше вже сьогодні.

entry.title: Real-time steering with LIVE planning
entry.content:
LIVE (Seamless) planning as the backend enabler for simplifications and real-time steering 

MOTIVATION

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organization is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organizational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognizing these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organizational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organizations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support – going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimize resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today’s business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The Value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering 
  2. Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC  
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC
  4. Is AI going to “retire” a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today’s volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC 
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning (THIS BLOG POST)
  8. PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering
  9. Self – service analytics and real-time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

INTRODUCTION

In my previous blog post of our BDC Business Steering series, I highlighted the key Planning & Analytics components of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), explaining how they help organizations streamline planning and analytics processes, enhance decision-making, boost efficiency and drive business value.

SAP BDC delivers Seamless Planning, a unified enterprise planning paradigm enabled by deep integration between SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Datasphere (DSP). Through this integration, SAC planning model data is stored directly in SAP Datasphere, providing native connectivity to SAP and non-SAP data sources as well as to SAP BDC Data Products. This ensures organizations can operate on trusted, consistent data structures fully aligned with operational data. Seamless Planning unifies planning logic with enterprise-grade data storage and governance. SAC remains the user-friendly planning experience and calculation engine, while Datasphere serves as the authoritative, governed persistence layer for plan and master data, integrated with other data sources. This architecture provides flexibility and multiple extensibility options by leveraging DSP’s ETL capabilities or applying advanced ML/AI through SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Databricks.

The latest evolution of Seamless Planning brings the integration of external data sources directly into SAC planning models as Live Versions, as detailed by @MaxGander in an excellent recent blog post. Introduced in Q4 2025, the External Live Version Data Sources innovation significantly reduces traditional data-import workflows in SAC planning models and eliminates data movement between planning domains, enabling a fully integrated, real-time planning experience.

In this blog post, I will illustrate a practical end-to-end use case that leverages External Live Versions in SAC planning powered by SAP Datasphere. The result is a real-time, holistic view of business insights that enhances steering agility, streamlines data management, and supports automated decision-making across the entire planning and analytics workflows.

A FEW WORDS ABOUT THE USE CASE EXAMPLE

 The example use case is about Brand Profitability Planning strategic process of aligning a company's branding strategies with its financial goals. The focus is on creating and maintaining a strong brand identity that not only resonates with customers but also drives long-term profitability.

With SAC and DSP Seamless Planning in SAP BDC, a Commerce Manager can quickly identify when brand commercial margin forecasts fall below budget and take proactive action by running simulations and predictive analyses using live connected reference data. They can also incorporate multiple influencers, integrated as external live data versions, to further refine projections. The CFO can then immediately assess the impact on the P&L, supported by real-time planning and analytics capabilities.

 The architecture and data flow are as follows:

  1. Actual profitability data from the SAP ERP system is stored in SAP Datasphere (DSP).
  2. This actual data is exposed as an external Live Version within the SAC Planning Brand Profitability Model, which resides in SAP DSP.
  3. Reference data (e.g. prior forecasts) is also integrated as an external Live Version in the same planning model.
  4. Influencer data used for predictive scenarios is integrated as an external Live Version to enrich the planning model.
  5. The SAC Planning Brand Profitability experience (stories, business logic, predictions, simulations, etc.) operates directly on these live data versions, while plan data is persisted into the underlying SAP DSP exposed table of the SAC Planning Brand Profitability Model.
  6. Real-time reporting and variance analysis are performed in SAP Analytics Cloud using the DSP Analytic Model.

STEP-BY-STEP EXECUTION

1. Brand Profitability Analysis

The Commerce Manager conducts multiple profitability analyses to identify underperforming brands and simulates strategies to improve their profitability. Analyzing the commercial figures indicates that we are currently under budget according to the current forecast. After a detailed analysis, examining each brand individually, identifies the responsible brand that requires attention and corrective measures to ensure the accuracy of the forecast plan.   

Step 1: Brand Profitability Analysis

Technical setup: The above SAC visualization story is built on top of a DSP Analytic Model for real-time variance analysis, integrating actuals and plan data through a DSP view that combines ERP actuals with the plan fact data from the SAC planning model. After each new forecast update is published, the plan data becomes real-time available in the variance analysis report—with no additional data movements, replications, or delays.

DSP: Brand Profitability Analytic ModelDSP: Brand Profitability View (Actual and Plan)

2. Driver-based Simulations / Scenario Planning

The Commerce Manager initiates a new forecast by creating multiple scenarios for the key profitability drivers. Scenarios 1 and 2 are driver-based, with scenario specific inputs applied accordingly (e.g., Scenario 01: pessimistic, Scenario 02: optimistic). These scenarios leverage the reference dataset, such as the previous forecast, made available as an external Live Version. For variance analysis during the simulation process, prior year actual is also integrated in real-time through a Live Version in SAC Planning, extended also with the planning business logic on-the-fly (e.g., Gross Margin (%) and Commercial Margin (%) calculations are executed for the actual and plan versions) to provide immediate, accurate comparisons.

Step 2: Driver-based Simulations / Scenario Planning

Technical setup: Actuals are integrated as a Live Version into the SAC Planning Brand Profitability model, enabling on-the-fly variance analysis against plan versions and supporting account and measure level calculations directly on live version data. The source for this actuals Live Version is a DSP view exposed for consumption.

Previous Forecast data is also integrated as a Live Version and serves as the baseline for driver-based scenario plan version calculations, allowing SAC data actions to perform business calculation calculations directly on top of live versions.

SAC: Brand Profitability Planning Model with External Live Versions

 

DSP: Exposed Views for Consumption as External Live Versions in Planning

 

SAC: Data Action - Scenario Creation leveraging Ref.Data External Live View

3. Predictive Scenario Planning

The third scenario is prediction-based, leveraging various KPI influencers alongside external data (e.g., the CPI index) sourced from the DSP Marketplace. The Commerce Manager updates the influencer values for the predictive model, and once configured, the predictive scenario can be executed. In this example, the predictive scenario for Gross Sales uses an external Live Version as the baseline, integrating actual data, CPI data, and the manager’s forecasted influencer values directly within SAP DSP.

Step 3: Predictive Scenario Planning

Technical setup: The baseline version for the predictive scenario is connected as an External Live Version in the SAC Planning Brand Profitability model, integrating actual data, CPI data, and the Commerce Manager’s forecasted influencer values directly from SAP DSP plan fact table. The source for this Predictive Live Version is a DSP view activated for consumption. A multi-action then executes the predictive scenario and triggers the additional data-action calculation steps required to produce the complete commercial margin for the predictive scenario. You can find more details about Time Series Forecasting and Predictive Planning in SAC in the blog post.

DSP: Predictive View used as External Live Version in Predictive Scenario

SAC: Multi-action with Predictive Scenario Calculation

 4. Simulating and creating the new Brand Forecast

After identifying optimization opportunities, the Commerce Manager can simulate proposed adjustments and assess their potential impact using SAP Analytics Cloud’s out-of-the-box Value Driver capabilities. Optionally, a stochastic risk simulation (Monte Carlo Simulation) for each scenario can be performed through the embedded SAC Compass functionality. Once satisfied with the simulation results and the projected figures of the preferred scenario, the Commerce Manager proceeds to publish this scenario to the brand forecast.

Step 4: Simulating and creating the new Brand Forecast

Technical setup: Standard out-of-the-box simulation capabilities are configured in SAC. In the value driver tree widget, the LY Actual calculation is enabled on top of the External Live Version containing the actual data.SAC: LY Actual Measure calculation using External Live Version

5. Brand Forecast Allocation

The commerce manager will execute the allocation of Brand Forecast to all product and customer combinations based on the on last year Gross Sales proportionate.

Step 5: Brand Forecast Allocation

 

 Technical setup: Standard out-of-the-box allocation and advanced formulas data action steps are configured in SAC.

SAC: Data Action Allocation Step

 

6. Updated Forecast and Financial view Evaluation

Once the updated forecast allocation is executed and all unassigned data is done, the commerce manager has to publish the results. Having that done, all results are available in the Brand Profitability Analysis and the P&L in real-time!

Step 6: Updated Forecast and Financial View Evaluation

 Technical setup: As outlined in Step 1, the SAC visualizations are built on DSP Analytic Models for real-time variance analysis, integrating actuals and plan data through DSP views. Once a new forecast update is published, the plan data becomes immediately available in the brand profitability analysis reports, such as the P&L, without any additional data movements, replications, or delays. See below the DSP view used for real-time P&L reporting, which leverages the Brand Profitability view along with views from other planning domains.

DSP: P&L view

SUMMARY

In this blog post, I demonstrated a practical end-to-end use case that leverages External Live Versions within the SAP BDC Seamless Planning architecture. This capability is a game changer, enabling real-time business steering by unifying actuals and plan data across planning domains to deliver a holistic, trusted view of performance.

Key takeaways from the use case:

  1. External Live Versions can be applied throughout the planning workflow—stories, data actions, predictions, calculations, and more.
  2. They enable robust variance analysis by enriching actuals with planning-model logic and calculations.
  3. Seamless Planning reduces data redundancy and lowers total cost of ownership.
  4. It provides the flexibility to decouple planning and reporting using DSP Analytic Model capabilities.
  5. Planning logic can be enriched through DSP’s ETL capabilities and advanced ML/AI extensions via SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Databricks within SAP Business Data Cloud.

Additionally, SAP BDC has the potential to further enhance Seamless Planning by:

  • Supporting planning-enabled intelligent applications that blend analytics with actionable workflows.
  • Enabling the direct consumption of BDC governed data products within planning processes.
  • Extending planning architectures to include platforms such as SAP Databricks and Snowflake.

This is just the beginning—more innovations are on the way!

entry.title: The Tech Stack is READY - There is so much beyond that. (TechEd 2025 presentation - Community talk)
entry.content:
Hi All

I had the pleasure of sharing some insights on AI journey for customers and partners at SAPTeched 2025 Berlin.

Let me share (the best I can in a BLOG) the content of my session.

I started by laying out that the presentation was based on a previous blog: The AI Stack Is Ready — Are You? The Challenge No Longer Is Technology . It is worth reading for context but I diggeed deeper in my TechEd session.

Let's dive in.

From a technology perspective, a GenAI (agent building) stack needs to provide the following capabilities:

  • Flexibility of choice of LLMs
  • Secure AI
  • RAG scenarios
  • Agent Building
  • Tool supporting
  • Orchestration

And we are there. Most platforms support that, at least in some way. That is true for SAP BTP and many others.

So we can consider that, the basic tools needed are provided. We can and should be able to start building.

Particularly around SAP, the latest TechEd announcements highlight the fast pace of innovation. More and more is coming.

MCP Support + ABAP LLM

RPT-1 and many other nice improvements

From a LLM perspective, the models keep getting better both in raw performance, Speed and cost.

As they keep getting better, a wrong approach would to say, the current models are not good enough or that we will decide to wait for next version. Believe me, you can get GPT6 performance today..... Let me explain.

Welcome TEST TIME COMPUTE

By applying some techniques that basically force the model to work harder at the question, will increase the performance.

An example of this is to ask for a brief answer vs compare that to an application that first determines a plan, proof it, execute it, revise and summarize the response. This is the principle of reasoning that are now more and more embedded in the SOTA (state of the art) LLMs, but you can keep pushing further....

SO, WHAT IS THE POINT MR. LEO???

Lets focus the discussion elsewhere. THE PROBLEM IS NO LONGER A TECHNICAL ONE.

Reality check

There are multiple reasons why that is the case. FIRST ONE is that the title of the article is misleading: It should be written 95% of the companies fail to demonstrate value. Sure a good chunk of that is due to use cases that delivered no or little value, true, but there is more to that story. 

In short:

  • Expectations are often not properly set;
  • It is natural that we get a high number if vailures - We are all experimenting and in this space, fail fast is the norm
  • There often a suboptimal approach (more on that later)
  • AND YES, it is hard to demonstrate value (methodology and tooling)

Lets set expectations right on very common misconceptions:

In ABAP you write 3 * 3 and the result will ALWAYS be 9 - This is deterministic

In GenAI (like with humans) it is probabilistic. The answer is 9 with 99.9999% prob. In other words, ask 5 billion people the same question and you won't get 100% either.

Garbage in = garbage out! This could not be more true in GenAI. If you data, assumptions or instructions are poor, expect S**t

And how many times I've heard:

Bus:"Lets put AI to solve the problem"

Tech:"describe me the problem?"

Bus: "AI should"figure it out" 

If you can't even explain the problem you are trying to solve it will be impossible to solve it.

Also, AI is not band-aid

Putting AI on a messy process will get you, well, a messy process with AI...

NOW, let focus on the IDEATION problem....

There is a reason why EVERY SINGLE VENDOR out there is after the "business cases". Good, valid, appealing and above all universal use cases are HARD to come by.

The nature of the game is, try often, fail fast, big return will come over time

In that process of getting your feet wet, you will try and mature your AI budgeting process.

Also, from a development perspective, as it is highly volatile, we recommend and approach from IDEA to POC to MVP to eventually PRODUT. Stepping stones.

In the ideation process, you need to evaluate the ideas in FEASIBILITY and VALUE. Ideally the Easiest and that will drive most business value will come to the top.

 

And how do you get there? 

Representation = You need tech folks who know the tech capabilities WITH the business folks who know the current business challenges.

Approach = BOTTOM UP approach is one where the ideation is around ideas to improve current processes while a BOTTOM UP approach is one where we re-think the process entirely with the new possibilities this technology brings

Also, effective enterprises adopt AI in 3 strategic levels

While company sets corporate wide transformational initiatives, departments should have their own plans and internal investments complemented by individuals trained and empowered to drive innovation in their own day to day.

The importance of OCM - Organizational Change Management

 

Lets talk beyond the BUILD phase

Cost reporting

You have 75 agents, each calling several LLMs cycles called by 2500 users. How much is it costing? who should pay for it? What is the ROI?

Helping value realization

You can only sucessfully demonstrate value if you determine a KPI, set a target and prove progress.

First determine a goal or a measurable outcome, establish a target and put in place what is required to measure it.

Only then, you will be able to demonstrate return on your investment (or not).

Understand now why 95% AI pilots fail ? 😉

entry.title: 「クリーン コア」は本当に新しい概念なのか？（Is "Clean Core" Really a New Concept?）
entry.content:
「クリーン コア」は本当に新しい概念なのか？ —— 温故知新で紐解く

(※English translation is available in the latter half of this article.)
(※本稿はJSUGテクニカル部会オピニオンリーダーとしての経験に基づく個人の見解であり、個人の所属企業およびJSUG等の組織の公式な見解を代表するものではありません。また文書の一部は生成AIにより作成しています。内容の正確性などを保証するものではありませんので、情報の活用はご自身の判断で行ってください。)

「それ、昔から言っていませんでしたか？」

JSUGテクニカル部会の活動を通じ、ユーザー企業の皆様や、SAP社のエキスパートたちと会話することが多い日々です。最近のコンファレンス等でも、「クリーン コア（Clean Core）」という言葉を聞かない日はありません。皆さんもそうではないでしょうか。

しかし、長年SAPの世界に身を置く皆様の中には、ある種の「既視感」を覚える方も多いはずです。

  • 「競争力の源泉とならない業務は標準機能を使おう（Fit to Standard）」 ・・・今

  • 「アドオンを作るなら、BAPIのような標準インターフェースを使おう」 ・・・少し前

  • 「アップグレード障害になるから、標準コードの直接修正（モディフィケーション）はやめよう」 ・・・20年ぐらい前

これらは、10年、いや20年前から私たちが議論し、目指してきた「あるべき姿」です。言葉こそ違えど、その大きな方向性に違いはないと感じています。

先日、部会に参加いただいた方から**「SAPさんはよく『クリーン コア』と言いますが、どうなれば『クリーンになった』と言えるのでしょうか？ 納得できる評価指標が欲しいのです」**という「問い」を投げかけられました。

その時、私は即答できませんでした。なぜなら、単に「アドオンを外に出しました（Side-by-Side）、公開APIだけを使っています」というだけでは、かつての「ABAPアドオンや、VB/Javaで作った外部アプリがBAPIを叩く構成」と本質的に何が違うのか、その差分を明確に説明できないもどかしさを感じたからです。

本稿では、この「変わらない本質」と、最新の拡張モデル（A-Dレベル）への進化、そしてAI時代における新たな意味を整理し、私たちが目指すべき方向性を再考したいと思います。

(この記事は SAPアドベントカレンダー 2025 の 12月8日分の記事として執筆しています。)

 

 

「場所」が変わっただけのスパゲッティ

まず、私たちが直視すべきは、「クリーン コア」という言葉が独り歩きし、「ERPの中にコードがなければ良い」という形式的なゴールに向かってしまっている懸念です。

海外のSAPコミュニティ（SAP Mentorsなど）では、既存の低品質なカスタムコードを、リファクタリング（設計の見直し）もせずにそのままクラウド基盤（SAP BTP）へ移行する手法に対し、**「分散モノリス（Distributed Monolith）」**という厳しい言葉で警鐘が鳴らされています。

「ゴミを部屋（ERP）からガレージ（BTP）に移しても、家全体が綺麗になったとは言えない」――ある海外アーキテクトの言葉は、痛烈に核心を突いています。

複雑怪奇なロジックをそのままクラウド上に持ち出し、大量のAPI通信を行えば、パフォーマンスは劣化し、障害時の原因究明は困難になります。これは私たちが過去、外部連携システムで苦労した歴史の繰り返しになりかねません。

「作る場所」を変えること自体は目的ではありません。「ビジネスの変化にどう対応するか」という目的を見失ってはいけないのです。

 

ストイックな理想から現実解へ：3-TierモデルからA-Dレベルへの進化

ここで、最近のSAPの戦略転換についても触れておく必要があります。当初、Clean Core戦略の実装ガイドラインとして「3-Tier（3階層）モデル」が提示されていました。

  • Tier 1: クラウドネイティブな公開APIのみを使用（Clean）

  • Tier 2: 公開APIがない場合のラッパー（Conditionally Clean）

  • Tier 3: 従来のABAP記述（Not Clean）

 

このモデルは非常にストイックで、「最新のクラウド作法（Tier 1）以外は認めない」という圧力が強いものでした。しかし、私たちJSUGテクニカル部会の議論においても、この点についてはSAP社の担当者に対して繰り返し疑問を呈してきました。

「BAPI（Business Application Programming Interface）は、そもそもSAP標準機能を安全に拡張するために、SAP自身が提供・保証してきた標準インターフェースではないか？ それを使っているのに『Not Clean』とされるのは矛盾している」

現場の実情としても、20年以上安定稼働しているBAPIを、単に「Tier 1の作法ではない」という理由だけで作り直すことは、コスト対効果の面で正当化できません。

実は、こうした声を上げていたのは日本のユーザーだけではなかったようです。ドイツのDSAGやアメリカのASUGといった世界中の主要なユーザーグループからも、「既存の安定したBAPI資産まで否定するのは現実的ではない」「Tier 2のラッパー作成は無駄な工数だ」といった同様のフィードバックが寄せられていました。

こうした世界中のユーザーコミュニティの「現場の声」を受け、SAPは2024年から2025年にかけて方針を軌道修正し、より現実的で洗練された**「Clean Core Extensibility Levels（A-Dレベル）」**という新モデルを導入しました。

(※各レベルの詳細な定義と3-Tierモデルとの比較については、本稿末尾のAppendixを参照ください)


新しい評価軸：A-Dレベルの衝撃

レベル判定定義と現場視点での解釈
Level AClean未来への投資。最新のABAP CloudとReleased APIを使用する理想形。新規開発はここを目指すべき。
Level BCleanBAPIの復権。ここが重要です。従来の**BAPIやIDoc（Classic API）**の使用が、正式に「Clean Core」の一部として認められました。これらは「クラウドネイティブ」ではないかもしれませんが、「アップグレードに対して安全（Upgrade Safe）」であるという実績が評価されたのです。
Level CConditional要監視。非公開の内部オブジェクトを使用しているが、変更ログ（Changelog）等でリスク管理ができる領域。
Level DNot Cleanレッドゾーン。モディフィケーション（標準コードの直接修正）やテーブル直接更新。これこそが排除すべき「真の技術的負債」です。

この進化は、SAPが「形式的な新しさ」よりも「実質的なシステムの安定性」を優先するという、エンジニアリングとしての誠実さ（Integrity）を取り戻した結果だと、評価しています。BAPIが一定レベルであれ「Clean」と認められたことは、過去からの一貫性という観点でも整合性が取れており、我々にとっては、既存資産（Brownfield）の移行における大きな現実解となります。

 

なぜ今、再び「標準化」なのか？ —— AIという「新たな評価者」

BAPIの利用が認められた（Level B）からといって、昔ながらのアドオン開発を続けて良いわけではありません。なぜなら、当時とは決定的に異なる**「AIの台頭」**という要素があるからです。

かつて、私たちが作った独自のアドオン機能から生成されたデータを解釈するのは、トレーニングを受けた「人間」でした。人間は、多少データ構造がいびつでも、文脈（コンテキスト）で補完して業務を回すことができました。

しかし、生成AI（SAP Jouleなど）は違います。

AIが正しくデータを読み解き、気の利いた回答をするためには、データモデルが標準的であり、意味（セマンティクス）が定義されている必要があります。ここで重要になるのが、例えば「Zテーブル（アドオンテーブル）」と「CDS View」の関係です。

技術解説：なぜ AI は「Zテーブル」が嫌いなのか？

  • Zテーブルの限界（コンテキストの欠如）

    私たちが長年作り続けてきたアドオンテーブル（Zテーブル）は、システム的（あるいはAIの視点）には単なる「データの箱」です。例えば、Z_SALES_TBL というテーブルに VAL1 という項目があったとします。ABAPプログラムの中では「これは受注金額だ」というロジックが書かれていますが、データベース自体はその意味を知りません。

    AIがこのテーブルを見ても、「VAL1 が何なのか」を理解できず、誤った回答（ハルシネーション）をするか、「回答不能」となります。AIにとって、Zテーブルは**「意味不明なブラックボックス」**なのです。（※アドオンABAPプログラムの隅々までAIが解析してくれれば、また話は違うかもしれませんが）

  • CDS View の役割（意味の付与）

これに対し、S/4HANAで推奨される CDS (Core Data Services) View は、データに「意味ラベル」を貼る技術です。

「この項目は『顧客ID』である」「この項目は『通貨コード』である」といった意味論（セマンティクス）を、コード（アノテーション）として定義します。これにより、AIや外部システムは、プログラムの中身を見なくてもデータの意味を理解できるようになります。

つまり、現代における「クリーン」の定義とは、単にアドオンコードの有無ではなく、**「自社のデータが、CDS View 等を通じて、AIや外部から『解釈可能』な状態（Semantic Rich）になっているか」**という点にシフトしているのです。

 

自社のシステムを評価する「3つの新しいものさし」

部会に参加いただいた方からの「どう評価すればいいか」という問いに対しては、従来の技術的な分類（TierモデルやABCDレベル）を超えた、ビジネス視点での以下の評価軸案を共有したいと思います。


1. ビジネス適合性と代謝（Fit & Metabolism）

「標準機能を使っているか」だけでなく、「競争力を生まない機能を捨てる決断ができているか」。

A-Dモデルで言えば、Level D（モディフィケーション）を徹底的に排除し、Level B（BAPI）であってもビジネス価値の低いものは廃棄（Retire）する。この「代謝」こそが重要です。

もう少し詳しく：「6R」による断捨離 —— 捨てることは、作ることより尊い

クラウド移行には「6R」というフレームワークがありますが、アドオン整理に当てはめると、優先順位はこうなります。

  • Retire（廃止・捨てる）: これが最重要です。ある調査では、カスタムコードの最大60%は実際には使われていないか、価値を失っていると言われているとのことです。

  • Repurchase（買い換え・代替）: 「この機能、SaaSや標準機能で代替できませんか？」。作るのではなく、標準に乗り換える勇気です。

  • Refactor（作り直し）: 差別化につながる重要な機能だけを選び、Level A (ABAP Cloud/BTP) で再構築します。

  • Re-platform（そのまま移行）: Level B (Classic API) として現状維持を認める。ただし、これには「いつか捨てる」という返済計画が必要です。

 

 

2. デリバリーのアジリティ（Speed & Safety）

「BTPを使っているか」ではなく、「機能リリースの頻度が向上したか」。

もし、クラウド上で開発しているのに、リリースのリードタイムが数ヶ月かかるなら、それはアーキテクチャかプロセスが間違っています。GoogleのDevOps研究（DORAメトリクス）のように、変更のリードタイムやデプロイ頻度を指標とし、「変更に強いシステム」になっているかを問うてください。

もう少し詳しく：「開発者の勘」から「判断の地図（フレームワーク）」を持つ

アジリティを検討する上では、アーキテクチャや採用する技術の検討も必要です。「この機能はS/4HANAの中に作るべきか（On-Stack）、BTPに出すべきか（Side-by-Side）？」という問いに対し、SAPは**「SAP Application Extension Methodology (AEM)」という標準的な意思決定ガイドを提供しています。

  • フェーズ1: そもそも拡張が必要か？（ビジネス要件の分解）

  • フェーズ2: 必要なのはUIか、ロジックか、データか？（技術特性の評価）

  • フェーズ3: どの技術を使うのが最適解か？（デシジョンツリーによる決定）

これらも、組織として一貫性のあるアーキテクチャを維持する一助になるかもしれません。

また、BTP上での開発が無法地帯にならないよう、「ゴールデン・パス（Golden Paths）」**、少し説明的にわかりやすく言えば「「開発標準」や「開発ガイドライン」（これらは主に文書やルール）に加えて、実際に作業を効率化・自動化するための**具体的な「仕組み」**がセットになったものといったところでしょうか。その際には、以下のような新しい（モダンな）技術の利用も積極的に検討すべきかと思います。

  • 宣言的に書く (CAP/RAP): 従来のように処理手順をゴリゴリ書くのではなく、CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model) や RAP(ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model) を使い、「データモデルと意図」を定義するスタイルへ移行しましょう。これにより、コード量が減り、AIとの親和性も高まります。

  • 疎結合にする (Event Mesh): APIでガチガチにつなぐのではなく、イベント駆動アーキテクチャを採用し、システム間の依存を減らす。

 

 

3. データとAIの受容力（Readiness）

「自社のデータは、AIが理解できる状態で管理されているか」。

主要なデータが標準テーブルまたはCDS View（意味論的ビュー）経由でアクセス可能か。Level A/Bどちらの実装であっても、データモデルの意味定義がなされているかどうかが、将来のAI活用を左右する分水嶺となります。

 

おわりに：本質は「ビジネス目標に基づく整理」

「クリーン コア」という言葉の表面的な意味だけに目を向けることは危険です。 本当に必要なのは、**「使うもの（標準）と作るもの（差別化）を、ビジネス目標を踏まえて整理する」**という、極めて当たり前の、しかし実行困難な原則です。

今回、SAPが3-TierモデルからA-Dモデルへ方針転換し、BAPIを復権させたことは、私たちユーザーコミュニティが声を上げ、ベンダーと対話を重ねた成果でもあります。コミュニティでの議論がなければ、現実と乖離した理想論がそのままルール化されていたかもしれません。

「クリーン コア」の取り組みは、ECC上のコードだけが対象ではなく、企業システム全体の問題です。また、ECCからのアップグレード時期だけの一過性の取り組みでもありません。

A-Dモデルの導入により、BAPIを含む既存資産の活用（Level B）が認められたことは、私たちにとって「移行評価のハードルが下がった」という朗報です。しかし、それに甘んじて「塩漬け」を続けてはなりません。AIという新しい「評価者」が、システムデータの品質を問い続けているからです。

過去のBAPI連携の時代から脈々と続くこの原則を、AIという新しい武器を手に入れた今だからこそ、技術論ではなく本質論・経営論として完遂する。それこそが、我々が目指すべき「真のクリーン コア」への道ではないでしょうか。

この場（SAP Community）や、JSUG等のユーザーコミュニティが、理想論やバズワードをただ受け入れる場ではなく、こうした現場のリアリティを持ち寄り、本質的な議論を戦わせ知見を深める場であり続けることを願っています。

本件についても、ぜひ、皆さんからのご意見などをいただければ幸いです。

最後になりますが、本稿作成にあたって、いつも議論を戦わせ議論を深めてくださるオピニオンリーダーの皆さん、サポートしてくださっているSAPの方々、新たな気付きを与えてくださるSAP Communityの皆さん、そして「問い」を投げかけてくださったK.Uさんに、この場を借りて感謝の言葉を述べさせていただきます。（それと、いろいろ情報の収集や疑問への回答に奔走してくれたAIくんにも。）

 

Appendix：3-TierモデルからA-Dレベルへの進化サマリ

SAP S/4HANA Clean Core 戦略における拡張性モデルのパラダイムシフト

本記事のベースとなった調査レポートの要点は以下の通りです。

1. 背景と課題

従来の「3階層（3-Tier）モデル」は、クラウドネイティブ（Tier 1）以外を「Not Clean」とする傾向が強く、既存の安定したABAP資産を多く抱える日本企業にとって実現困難でした。JSUG等のユーザーコミュニティからは、「SAP標準機能であるBAPIを使った拡張まで否定されるのは矛盾している」との指摘がなされていました。

2. 新モデル（A-Dレベル）の詳細定義

SAPは拡張性を4つの成熟度レベルで再定義し、実用的な運用指針を示しました。

  • Level A (Clean Core / Future Safe):

    • 定義: 公開済みAPI (Released API) のみを使用。ABAP CloudまたはBTPでの実装。

    • 推奨: 新規開発の第一選択肢。AI活用に最適。

  • Level B (Clean Core / Upgrade Safe):

    • 定義: クラシックAPI（BAPI, IDoc, RFC等）およびクラシックフレームワーク（ALV, Dynpro等）を使用する拡張。

    • 3-Tierとの違い: ここが最大のパラダイムシフトです。3-Tierモデルでは、これらは「Tier 3（Not Clean）」とみなされるか、または「Tier 2（ラッパー作成）」として隠蔽することが求められていました。

    • 革新点: 新モデルでは、ラッパーを作成せずとも、BAPIを直接呼び出すことが「Clean Core」として公式に認定されました。これにより、「安定しているが古いためクラウド非対応」とされていた大量の既存コードが、改修不要で合格ラインに達することになります。

  • Level C (Conditional / Monitor):

    • 定義: 非公開の内部オブジェクトを使用しているが、変更ログ (Changelog / SYCM) でリスクを監視・管理することを条件に許容される拡張。

    • 3-Tierとの違い: 従来は一律に「Tier 3（禁止）」とされていたグレーゾーンに対し、「管理されたリスク（Managed Risk）」としての生存権が与えられました。代替APIが存在しない場合の現実的な回避策として機能します。

  • Level D (Not Clean / High Risk):

    • 定義: モディフィケーション、直接テーブル更新。即時の排除・改修が求められます。

3. 戦略的示唆

Level Bの認定により、Brownfield移行におけるコスト圧力を軽減しつつ、Level D（真の負債）の排除にリソースを集中させることが可能となります。これは「理想」から「現実解」への転換であり、Clean Core戦略の実効性を高めるものです。

本記事の執筆にあたり、以下の議論や資料を参考にしています。深掘り学習にお役立てください。

    • “Keep the core clean” statement considered harmful (Wout de Waal 氏のブログ): 「コアをクリーンに」という言葉が招く誤解と、分散システムの複雑性（分散モノリス）について警鐘を鳴らした必読の記事。

    • (https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/quot-keep-the-core-clean-quot-statement-considered-harmful/ba-p/13568928)

  • SAP公式のクリーンコア・拡張戦略

    • Clean Core Extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud (SAP Whitepaper): SAPが定義する最新の拡張モデル（Clean Core Levels A-D）やガバナンスに関する公式ホワイトペーパー。

    • (https://www.sap.com/documents/2024/09/20aece06-d87e-0010-bca6-c68f7e60039b.html)

    • Understanding DORA: A DevOps Guide for Side-by-Side Extension Developers: GoogleのDevOps研究（DORA）をSAP BTP開発に適用し、デリバリーパフォーマンスを測定する方法についての解説。

** Is "Clean Core" Really a New Concept? — Unraveling it by Revisiting the Past**

(※This article is a personal opinion based on my experience as an opinion leader of the JSUG Technical SIG, and does not represent the official views of the individual's company or organizations such as JSUG. Also, parts of the document were created using generative AI. We cannot guarantee the accuracy of the content, so please use the information at your own discretion.)

"Haven't We Said This Before?"

Through my activities with the JSUG (Japan SAP User Group) Technical Committee, I spend my days talking with fellow user companies and SAP experts. Recently, not a day goes by without hearing the words "Clean Core" at conferences. I’m sure many of you feel the same.

However, for those of us who have been in the SAP world for a long time, doesn't this bring about a certain sense of déjà vu?

  • "Use standard functions for non-differentiating processes (Fit to Standard)"... Current

  • "If you build add-ons, use standard interfaces like BAPI"... A little while ago

  • "Stop directly modifying standard code (Modifications) because it hinders upgrades"... About 20 years ago

These are the "ideal states" we have been discussing and aiming for over the last 10, or even 20 years. While the terminology has changed, I feel the broad direction hasn't fundamentally shifted.

Recently, a participant in our committee asked me a probing question:

"SAP often talks about 'Clean Core,' but when can we actually say a system is 'Clean'? I want a convincing evaluation metric."

At that moment, I couldn't give an immediate answer. Simply saying, "We moved add-ons outside (Side-by-Side) and are only using public APIs," didn't feel satisfying. How is that fundamentally different from the architectures of the past where external VB or Java apps called BAPIs? I felt a frustration in being unable to clearly articulate the difference.

In this post, I want to organize this "unchanging essence," the evolution to the latest extensibility model (A-D Levels), and the new meaning in the AI era to rethink the direction we should be heading.

(This article is written for the SAP Advent Calendar 2025, December 8th entry.)

 

 

Spaghetti That Just Changed Its Location

First, we must face the concern that "Clean Core" is walking on its own as a formal goal of simply "having no code inside the ERP."

In the global SAP community (including SAP Mentors), there are strict warnings against the practice of "Lift & Shift"—taking existing low-quality custom code and moving it to a cloud platform (SAP BTP) without refactoring (redesigning). This creates what is known as a "Distributed Monolith."

"Moving rubbish from your room to the garage doesn't mean the house is clean." — This quote from an overseas architect cuts to the core of the issue.

If you take complex logic and move it to the cloud as-is, executing massive amounts of API calls, performance will degrade, and troubleshooting during failures will become a nightmare. This could become a repeat of the history where we struggled with external system integrations in the past.

"Changing the location" where we build is not the goal. We must not lose sight of the true purpose: "How do we respond to business changes?"

 

 

From Stoic Ideal to Reality: Evolution from the 3-Tier Model to A-D Levels

Here, we must also touch upon SAP's recent strategic shift. Initially, the "3-Tier Extensibility Model" was presented as the implementation guideline for the Clean Core strategy.

  • Tier 1: Use only cloud-native public APIs (Clean)

  • Tier 2: Wrappers for when public APIs are unavailable (Conditionally Clean)

  • Tier 3: Traditional ABAP coding (Not Clean)

This model was extremely stoic, creating strong pressure that "anything other than the latest cloud practices (Tier 1) is unacceptable."

However, within the JSUG Technical Committee, we repeatedly questioned SAP on this point:

"BAPI (Business Application Programming Interface) is a standard interface provided and guaranteed by SAP itself to safely extend standard functions. Isn't it contradictory to label it 'Not Clean' when we are using SAP's own standard?"

From a practical standpoint, forcing a rewrite of BAPIs that have been running stably for over 20 years, simply because they "don't fit Tier 1 practices," cannot be justified in terms of cost-effectiveness.

It turns out we weren't alone. Major user groups worldwide, such as DSAG in Germany and ASUG in the US, provided similar feedback: "Denying existing stable BAPI assets is unrealistic" and "Creating Tier 2 wrappers is wasted effort."

In response to these "voices from the field" from user communities globally, SAP corrected its course between 2024 and 2025, introducing a more realistic and sophisticated new model: "Clean Core Extensibility Levels (A-D Levels)."

(For detailed definitions of each level and a comparison with the 3-Tier model, please refer to the Appendix at the end of this article.)

 

 

A New Evaluation Axis: The Impact of A-D Levels

LevelVerdictDefinition and Interpretation from the Field
Level ACleanInvestment for the Future. The ideal form using the latest ABAP Cloud and Released APIs. New developments should aim for this.
Level BCleanThe Return of BAPI. This is crucial. The use of traditional BAPIs and IDocs (Classic APIs) has been officially recognized as part of "Clean Core." While not "cloud-native," they were evaluated as "Upgrade Safe."
Level CConditionalMonitor Required. Uses non-public internal objects, but risks can be managed via Changelogs, etc.
Level DNot CleanRed Zone. Modifications (direct changes to standard code) and direct table updates. This is the "true technical debt" that must be eliminated.

I evaluate this evolution as SAP prioritizing "substantive system stability" over "formal novelty," thereby regaining engineering integrity. The fact that BAPIs are recognized as "Clean" (even if at a certain level) maintains consistency with the past, providing a significant and realistic solution for us user companies migrating existing assets (Brownfield).

 

 

Why "Standardization" Again Now? — AI as the "New Evaluator"

Just because BAPI usage is allowed (Level B) doesn't mean we should continue with old-school add-on development habits. There is a decisive difference from the past: the "Rise of AI."

In the past, the ones interpreting the data generated by our unique add-on functions were "humans" who were trained to understand it. Humans could supplement "context" to work around slightly malformed data structures.

However, Generative AI (like SAP Joule) is different.

For AI to correctly interpret data and provide smart answers, the data model must be standard, and its meaning (Semantics) must be defined. Here, the relationship between "Z-tables (Add-on tables)" and "CDS Views" becomes critical.

 

Technical Deep Dive: Why Does AI Hate "Z-Tables"?

  • The Limit of Z-Tables (Lack of Context)

    The add-on tables (Z-tables) we have built for years are, to AI, just "mysterious data boxes." For example, if there is a column named VAL1 in a table called Z_SALES_TBL, the program logic might treat it as an order amount, but the database definition itself holds no such meaning.

    If AI looks at this table, it can't understand "what VAL1 is." It will either give a wrong answer (Hallucination) or say "I can't answer."

  • The Role of CDS Views (Injecting Meaning)

    In contrast, CDS (Core Data Services) Views, recommended in S/4HANA, attach "Semantic Labels" to data.

    By defining semantics like "This field is a 'Currency Code'," AI can understand the meaning of the data without looking inside the program logic.

In other words, the modern definition of "Clean" has shifted. It's not just about whether the code sits on BTP (Level A) or S/4HANA (Level B); it's about "whether your data is in a state that is 'interpretable' (Semantic Rich) by AI and the outside world through CDS Views."

 

 

"3 New Yardsticks" to Evaluate Your System

To answer the user's question—"How should we evaluate it?"—I would like to share the following evaluation axes based on a business perspective, premised on SAP's A-D Levels (technical indicators).

 

1. Business Fit & Metabolism

It's not just "Are we using standard functions?", but "Can we make the decision to discard functions that don't generate competitiveness?"

In terms of the A-D model, thoroughly eliminate Level D (Modifications), and even for Level B (BAPI), discard (Retire) those with low business value. This "metabolism" is what matters.

The "6R" Decluttering

  • Retire: Most important. Discard unused code.

  • Repurchase: Switch to SaaS or standard functions.

  • Refactor: Rebuild only differentiating areas in Level A (ABAP Cloud/BTP).

  • Re-platform: Recognize Level B (Classic API) as status quo. However, a repayment plan is needed.

 

2. Delivery Agility (Speed & Safety)

It's not "Are we using BTP?", but "Has the frequency of functional releases improved?"

If you are developing on the cloud but the lead time for a release takes months, the architecture or process is wrong. Like DORA metrics, use metrics like Change Lead Time and Deployment Frequency as your guide.

More Detail: Moving from "Developer's Intuition" to a "Decision Map (Framework)"

When considering agility, it is also necessary to examine architecture and the technologies adopted. In response to the question, "Should this function be built inside S/4HANA (On-Stack) or out on BTP (Side-by-Side)?", SAP provides a standard decision-making guide called the "SAP Application Extension Methodology (AEM)."

  • Phase 1: Is an extension actually necessary in the first place? (Decomposition of business requirements)

  • Phase 2: Is the need for UI, logic, or data? (Evaluation of technical characteristics)

  • Phase 3: Which technology is the optimal solution? (Decision via Decision Tree)

These can help maintain a consistent architecture as an organization.

Furthermore, to prevent development on BTP from becoming a "lawless zone," "Golden Paths" are essential. To explain this descriptively, you can think of it as a set that combines "development standards" and "development guidelines" (which are mainly documents and rules) with concrete "mechanisms" to actually streamline and automate the work. In this context, active consideration should be given to utilizing new (modern) technologies such as the following:

  • Write Declaratively (CAP/RAP): Instead of writing extensive procedural steps as done traditionally, shift to a style using CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model) or RAP (ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model) to define "data models and intent." This reduces code volume and increases affinity with AI.

  • Make Loosely Coupled (Event Mesh): Instead of tightly binding systems with APIs, adopt an event-driven architecture to reduce dependencies between systems.

 

3. Data & AI Readiness

"Is your company's data managed in a state that AI can understand?"

Are major data points accessible via standard tables or CDS Views (Semantic Views)? Regardless of whether the implementation is Level A or B, whether the data model has semantic definitions will be the watershed moment for future AI utilization.

 

 

Conclusion: The Essence is "Organization Based on Business Goals"

Looking only at the superficial meaning of the word "Clean Core" is dangerous. What is truly needed is the principle—"organizing what to use (Standard) and what to make (Differentiation) based on business goals." This is an extremely obvious, yet difficult-to-execute principle.

The fact that SAP shifted its policy from the 3-Tier model to the A-D model and reinstated BAPI is a result of us, the user community, raising our voices and engaging in dialogue with the vendor. Without community discussion, idealistic theories detached from reality might have remained the rule.

"Clean Core" initiatives are not just about code on ECC, but a problem for the entire enterprise system. Furthermore, it is not a one-time initiative just for the timing of the upgrade from ECC.

The introduction of the A-D model and the recognition of existing asset utilization (Level B), including BAPI, is good news for us as it "lowers the hurdle for migration evaluation." However, we must not be complacent and leave systems "pickled" in their old state. This is because AI, the new "evaluator," is constantly questioning the quality of system data.

Completing this principle, which has flowed continuously since the era of BAPI integration, not as a technical theory but as a fundamental and management theory because we now have the new weapon of AI—that is the path to the "True Clean Core" we should aim for.

I hope that this place (SAP Community) and user communities like JSUG continue to be places that do not just accept idealisms or buzzwords, but bring together these on-the-ground realities to fight out essential debates and deepen our collective knowledge.

I would be very happy to hear your opinions on this matter as well.

Finally, I would like to use this space to express my gratitude to the opinion leaders who always engage in and deepen these debates, the SAP folks who support us, the SAP Community members who provide new insights, and K.U. who gave me this "Question." (And also to the AI assistant who ran around gathering information and answering my doubts.)

Appendix: Report Summary

Paradigm Shift in Extensibility Models for SAP S/4HANA Clean Core Strategy

The following are the key points from the research report that formed the basis of this article:

1. Background and Issues

The traditional "3-Tier Model" had a strong tendency to label anything other than cloud-native (Tier 1) as "Not Clean," making it difficult for Japanese companies with large amounts of stable existing ABAP assets to implement. User communities like JSUG pointed out the contradiction that "even extensions using BAPI, an SAP standard function, are denied."

2. Detailed Definition of New Model (A-D Levels)

SAP redefined extensibility into four maturity levels and presented practical operational guidelines.

  • Level A (Clean Core / Future Safe):

    • Definition: Uses only Released APIs. Implementation on ABAP Cloud or BTP.

    • Recommendation: First choice for new development. Optimal for AI utilization.

  • Level B (Clean Core / Upgrade Safe):

    • Definition: Extensions using Classic APIs (BAPI, IDoc, RFC, etc.) and Classic Frameworks (ALV, Dynpro, etc.).

    • Difference from 3-Tier: This is the core of the paradigm shift. In the 3-Tier model, these were considered "Tier 3 (Not Clean)" or required concealment as "Tier 2 (Wrapper Creation)."

    • Innovation: In the new model, directly calling BAPIs without creating wrappers has been officially certified as "Clean Core". This means that a massive amount of existing code, which was considered "stable but not cloud-ready because it's old," now reaches the passing grade without modification.

  • Level C (Conditional / Monitor):

    • Definition: Extensions using non-public internal objects but are permitted provided risks are monitored and managed via change logs (Changelog / SYCM).

    • Difference from 3-Tier: The gray zone, which was uniformly considered "Tier 3 (Prohibited)" in the past, has been given the right to exist as "Managed Risk". It functions as a realistic workaround when no alternative API exists.

  • Level D (Not Clean / High Risk):

    • Definition: Modifications, direct table updates. Immediate elimination/renovation is required.

3. Strategic Implications

Level B certification allows for alleviating cost pressures in Brownfield migrations while concentrating resources on eliminating Level D (true debt). This represents a shift from "ideal" to "realistic solution," enhancing the effectiveness of the Clean Core strategy.

Reference Information & Related Links

The following discussions and materials were referenced in writing this article. Please use them for deeper learning.

  • Critical Considerations on Clean Core

    • “Keep the core clean” statement considered harmful (Wout de Waal's Blog): A must-read article sounding the alarm on the misunderstandings invited by "Clean Core" and the complexity of distributed systems (Distributed Monolith).

    • (https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/quot-keep-the-core-clean-quot-statement-considered-harmful/ba-p/13568928)

  • SAP Official Clean Core & Extension Strategy (A-D Model)

    • Clean Core Extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud (SAP Whitepaper): The official whitepaper defining the latest extension models (Clean Core Levels A-D) and governance.

    • (https://www.sap.com/documents/2024/09/20aece06-d87e-0010-bca6-c68f7e60039b.html)

  • Criteria for System Extension

    • SAP Application Extension Methodology: The official methodology and decision tree for deciding "Should we build On-Stack or Side-by-Side?".

    • (https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-btp-guidance-framework/sap-application-extension-methodology/sap-application-extension-methodology-overview)

  • Agility Evaluation Metrics (DORA Metrics)

    • Understanding DORA: A DevOps Guide for Side-by-Side Extension Developers: An explanation on applying Google's DevOps research (DORA) to SAP BTP development to measure delivery performance.

    • (https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/understanding-dora-a-devops-guide-for-side-by-side-extension-developers/ba-p/14226907)
